abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Small-scale
            Agricultural Infrastructure Project I Mexico was to benefit
            directly 30,000 rural families by irrigating 56,000 ha of
            dry lands, mostly (65 percent) by means of tube wells;
            draining 36,000 ha of wet lands; and constructing 50
            livestock production schemes. Of the total cost of the
            project, US$143.7, about 77 percent was going to be invested
            in irrigation, 12 percent in drainage and 11 percent in
            livestock infrastructure. Beneficiaries were going to
            participate in financing construction of the works, and they
            would also cover the full cost of operating and maintaining
            the schemes. About 22,300 rural families benefited directly
            as a result of the project, with indirect employment of
            another 10,000 expected. The estimated economic rate of
            return (ERR), excluding the livestock component, was 12
            percent. The result is lower than the ERR of 23 percent
            estimated at appraisal because of the following differences:
            (a) economic prices during the project implementation period
            were lower than those projected at appraisal; (b) the total
            area benefited by investment on irrigation and drainage was
            smaller by about 25 percent and the project total cost
            somewhat higher by about 20 percent than those estimated at
            appraisal; (c) about 15 percent of tube well investments
            were lost due to unproductive wells; and (d) subproject
            investments, specially storage dams, took longer to
            construct than expected at appraisal.

            livestock infrastructure. Beneficiaries were going to

0.cdata!:
Mexico - Proyecto de pequenas obras de
            infraestructura para el desarrollo agropecuario

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would promote increased
            agricultural and livestock production through the execution
            of about 250 irrigation, drainage and livestock subprojects:
            infrastructure for irrigation including tubewells, storage
            dam, and pumping from rivers; drainage; and livestock
            raising. Some 30,000 low-income families would directly
            benefit from project works. Average annual family income for
            beneficiaries of irrigation and drainage projects is
            expected to increase from about US$500 before the project to
            about US$2,300 at full development four to five years later.
            Incomes of beneficiaries of the livestock development
            subprojects are expected to increase from an estimated
            average level of about US$200 without the project to about
            US$1,400 at full development, eight to ten years later.
